description.narrative: The project aims to substantively support an improved knowledge of region’s flood risk, causes and appropriate responses among authorities and other stakeholders;
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Reducing flood risk and improving integrated flood risk management

activity-description.narrative: Reducing flood risk and improving integrated flood risk management

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Output 2: 2.1 Number of people in flood risk zones benefiting from a functional flash flood early warning and public alert system 2.2 Improved institutional response to future flood events (measured during simulated scenarios as part of drills) 2.3 % of municipalities in the Polog region with disaster preparedness plans and protocols
Output 3: 3.2 To be defined as part of the FRMP during 2020
Output 4: 4.1 % of harmonization of the national legislation with the objectives of the EU Floods Directive 4.2 Increase in number and value of flood risk mitigation investment decisions as a result of the national level strategy and action plan
Outcome 5 (SDC & SECO): 5.1 Number of targeted stakeholders/population aware of the contemporary flood risk management/DRR options and approaches 5.2 Number of replications of concepts /models prototyped by the project in the country and/or in the region

comment.narrative:
Output 2: 2.1 There is currently no functional flash-flood early warning and public-alter system in place in any part of the country (including Polog). Such a system is being introduced as part of an ongoing UNDP-backed project, covering a limited part of the entire basin area. 2.2 Recent flood events revealed major deficiencies in the response capacity of institutions and communities resulting in casualties and significant damages 2.3 None of the municipalities in the basin have access to comprehensive preparedness plans and response protocols in disastrous situations
Output 3: 3.2 To be defined as part of the FRMP during 2020
Output 4: 4.1 National legislation isn’t harmonized with the objectives of the EU Floods Directive 4.2 Uncoordinated and uninformed investments in flood risk mitigation (to be defined in 2019) due to the lack of national-level strategy and action plan 4.3 Inefficient risk financing mechanisms and limited penetration of insurance product on the market
Outcome 5 (SDC & SECO): 5.1 There is limited knowledge among key personnel of the institutions charged with flood risk management/DRR responsibilities (tbd during preparatory stage) 5.2 Only very limited number of projects in the country are aligned with the contemporary principles of DRR and flood risk management

Outcome 2: • Operationalization of the meteorological and hydrological monitoring system; • Design of early warning and public alert system for floods; • Feasibility assessment of preparedness options for Polog region’s municipalities • Developing protocols for emergency situations • Initiating update of municipal emergency action plans in line with recommendations of feasibility assessments
Outcome 3 • Development of detailed technical documentation for selected priority torrential streams and other sediment sources • Launching of financial instrument for improving energy efficiency in private and public buildings in selected municipalities • Implementation of energy efficiency projects for public/private buildings in two pilot municipalities
Outcome 4: • Consolidation of existing and development of new flood risk assessments for basins that are not covered • Launching of national-level flood risk mitigation strategy Outcome 3:
• Development of detailed technical documentation for selected priority torrential streams and other sediment sources • Launching of financial instrument for improving energy efficiency in private and public buildings in selected municipalities • Implementation of energy efficiency projects for public/private buildings in two pilot municipalities
Outcome 4: • Consolidation of existing and development of new flood risk assessments for basins that are not covered • Launching of national-level flood risk mitigation strategy
Outcome 5: • Identification of opportunities for building partnerships between Swiss and Macedonian institutions on issues relevant to flood risk management/DRR

Outcome 2: - Full re-activation and upgrade of the monitoring system was impeded by the pandemic situation and small delays resulted in the installation of the meteorological and hydrological monitoring stations. Works were implemented under difficult circumstances considering the harsh conditions at the locations of the monitoring stations, and the need to deal with sensitives stemming from the perceptions of the local communities on the monitoring stations. - The Programme developed detailed requirements for a comprehensive study to improve overall preparedness to floods and other related geohazards in the entire Polog region. The study was launched in the reporting period and the expert team was contracted in August.
Outcome 3: - Shipkovica torrent design is under preparation - Sediment study under preparation - Energy efficient measure implemented in Bogovinje and Tetovo
Outcome 4: - National-level flood risk mitigation strategy outlined
Outcome 5: - Since one of the main objectives of the project is the continuous capacity building of responsible personnel, the Programme continued networking and transfer of knowledge throughout all its components. For example, in order to make best use of experiences so far in the Polog and Southeast planning regions in DRR, the Programme is facilitating exchange between two UNDP-implemented projects (SECO/SDC funded Polog project and SEE Urban project funded by the EU). The focus on the exchange are the opportunities provided by inter-municipal cooperation in the context of DRR at local level. - Important international/Swiss experience is already being transferred to key beneficiaries through different consultancies and in the course of the stakeholder events (e.g., by the International Technical Adviser, and urban river flooding management experts from Switzerland).

Outcome 2: - Development of the feasibility assessment of preparedness options for Polog region’s municipalities - Develop feasible early warning system based on the experts’ assessment report and overall general preparedness plan for Polog by the end of 2021 - Conceptualizing and piloting a community-based early warning system through involvement of relevant institutions and potentially affected communities.
Outcome 3: - Launching procedure for grants targeting energy efficiency in households in Vrapciste Municipality - Together with the municipalities develop long-term financing instruments to ensure continuity of such feasible solutions for improving energy efficiency of households in the future. - Completing the process of development of the sediment management study and prioritizing the mitigation interventions - Development of detailed technical documentation for selected priority sediment sources and landslides. - Implement sediment control and landslide stabilization measures in identified high risk zones.
Outcome 4: - Facilitation in implementation of the national-level flood risk mitigation strategy and action plan - Facilitate the process of instituting the inter-municipal cooperation mechanism as a permanent administrative body shared by all municipalities
Outcome 5: - Continuation of knowledge and skills development of key institutions through different involvement of relevant staff in different programme activities

Outcome 2: 1. The Overall preparedness study and final assessment of preparedness options for Polog region municipalities was completed. 2. The initial concept for the early warning system was prepared. Following the results from the study and the analysis conducted and presented in the one, will also serve as a starting point in designing the early warning system at regional scale (expected to be delivered at the end of 2022).
Outcome 3: 1. The Municipal Council of Vrapciste already adopted a decision to start with the most feasible solutions for improving energy efficiency of households mostly in rural areas which have limited access to heating options. Financial contribution is also approved by the Council, to be provided from the Municipal Budget. 3. Tendering process for selection of SP for development of design fpr stabilization of 7 landslides is completed, and contracts signed. The selected sites are: Jelovjane, Bozovce, Senokos, Germo, Pirok, Staro Selo, Dolna Lesnica and Pena.
5. In close cooperation with the National Forestry Agency, the Programme supported supply of the irrigation system for the plant nursery in Kumanovo, to provide plants for future reforestation activities. The installation is planned for January 2022.
Outcome 4: 1. The preparation of the national-level flood mitigation strategy and an action plan is in an advanced stage. So far, no prioritization of such needs has been carried out on a national level, i.e. the central government perspective. Besides completing assessments for 7 river basins of the country for which these didn’t exist, the Programme supported application of a consolidated methodology for updating all prior assessments and bringing them to the same level of detail.
2. The Programme continued the support and facilitation the process of institutionalization the inter-municipal cooperation mechanism as a permanent administrative body (Polog Network) shared by all municipalities
Outcome 5: Important international/Swiss experience is already being transferred to key beneficiaries through different consultancies and in the course of the stakeholder events (e.g., by the International Technical Adviser, and urban river flooding management experts from Switzerland). Further continuation of transfer of knowledge will be implemented in the upcoming Case Study for Poroj, where the Programme consultant Mr. Markus Zimmermann will bring knowledge and experience from similar cases in Switzerland.

Outcome 2: • Activation of the meteorological and hydro-logical monitoring system. • Developing (co-design of) protocols for emergency situations. • Launching of the preparation of emergency action plans for the institutions of the emergency response system. • Launching of capacity building and awareness raising activities for instituting the early warning system Outcome 3 • Launching a comprehensive feasibility study for conceptualizing and comparing different torrential flooding mitigation interventions. • Development of detailed technical documentation for selected priority torrential streams; • Launching of a feasibility study on energy efficiency options to reduce pressure on forest cover, including financing models. • Continued cooperation with the Public Forest Enterprise to ensure that forest regeneration measures/forest cover management priorities are integrated in the respective forest management plans. Outcome 4: • .Launching of the process for formulation of a national-level flood risk mitigation strategy and action plan. • Identification of capacity development priorities for key institutions in line with the anticipated national-level reforms (e.g., through harmonization of the national legislation with the objectives of the EU Floods Directive). Outcome 5 • Initiating partnership between Macedonian and Swiss educational and research organizations and students, including defining common research priorities. • Support a study visit for networking and transfer of knowledge of responsible Macedonian institutions and relevant Swiss partners.

Outcome 2: • The Flood Risk Management Plan (FRMP) suggested full re-activation and an upgrade of the monitoring system by applying phased approach, so as to give the responsible institutions time to adapt to the increased demand for operation and maintenance. Preparatory construction works were carried out and one central climatological station, eight rainfall stations, and eleven hydrological station (five of which will act as flood alarm stations) were put into operation as an optimal monitoring solution. The necessary technology (e.g., monitoring stations and software) was already provided. • Preliminary activities have been undertaken to review the institutional framework and existing early warning systems including management responses and roles of different institutions. The sociological research that was conducted in the region provided information on demographic and socio-economic status of the local population as well as information on the knowledge, views and perceptions about floods. This information helped designing a concept for a study to improve preparedness to floods in the entire Polog region. The study will concentrate on the key elements of the preparedness system, including: a) co-design of the early warning system; b) design and testing of emergency response protocols; c) community mobilization and awareness raising; d) proposals on resources required at local level aiming to improve coping capacities of institutions under different risk scenarios. • Support is provided to municipalities to consolidate and interlink their emergency response plans (e.g., crisis management and protection and rescue plans) in line with the findings of the FRMP and all relevant ongoing and planned studies (e.g., the planned study on improving preparedness at a basin-level). The existing local level/municipal emergency response plans were revised, updated and brought into correlation, emphasizing the importance of sharing resources and improving cooperation to improve overall preparedness. • With the support of the International Senior Technical Adviser, the programme team has developed a concept for a study to improve preparedness to floods in the entire Polog region. The study will be launched at the beginning of 2020 and will concentrate on the key elements of the preparedness system, including community mobilization and awareness raising. As part of this efforts, the new early warning system and emergency response capacity will be tested as part of drills to be organized in cooperation with multiple stakeholders. Outcome 3 • Risk-based prioritization of torrential flooding for the entire Upper Vardar River Basin was carried out which enabled the project to make more informed investment decisions for mitigation actions. For this purpose, about twenty most significant torrential streams were analyzed in great detail by applying sophisticated risk assessment methodologies and advanced mathematical modeling in combination of field investigations. The prioritization of the main sediment sources in the basin, along with approaches to their future management is carried out as part of the sediment management study. The study will combine investigations of erosion and landslide processes, i.e. analysis of sediment generation and transport regardless of its sources. About 15-20 most significant sediment sources (landslides and torrential streams) was analyzed through field visits by mixed team of experts (e.g. geologists, geotechnical engineers, geomorphologists, hydrologists/hydraulic engineers) to collect all data necessary to generate and compare different management alternatives against a wide range of feasibility factors (e.g. financial, economic, social, environmental). • Through engaged Swiss expertise, design concepts and design guidelines/specifications for adjustment of existing designs for regulation of Vardar River (Jegunovce section), and Bogovinjska Reka (Bogovinje and Brvenica municipalities) are prepared as well as guidelines for preparation of new technical design for Vardar River along the Gostivar section are provided. Design guidelines are used as foundation for preparation of TORs for development of detailed technical documentation for ecosystem-oriented urban river flood management design for Vardar River downstream the City of Gostivar as well as for adjustment of existing designs for regulation of Vardar River (Jegunovce section), and Bogovinjska Reka (Bogovinje and Brvenica municipalities). The guidelines provide contemporary approaches (e.g., nature-based solutions, Eco-DRR, etc.), mindful of the multitude of constraints imposed by the local setting. • Feasibility Assessment of Alternative Heating and Energy Efficiency Options for Firewood-Heated Households in the Polog Region was prepared. Through this assignment the most feasible solutions for long-term reduction of the demand for wood for heating of region’s households were introduced through alternative energy sources and improving energy efficiency of houses The study placed special emphasis on those parts of the region with the most concentrated firewood consumption and loss of forest cover where pilot activities are expected to take place as part of the programme. The study suggests solutions for local-level/municipal financial assistance (e.g., in the form of subsidies) to support household shift toward improved energy efficiency. By this the municipalities will be provided with a long-term financing model for introducing energy efficient measures within their respective communities. Based on assessment of overall awareness of target communities, and on the basis of the recommendations of the study, basic material for future awareness raising/community outreach activities was produced. Finally, the study simulates the long-term effects of spreading the most feasible set of energy efficiency measures across the region, for example in terms of reduction of demand for firewood, economic benefits for the households, and environmental effects (e.g., reduced emissions of greenhouse gases). • Initial contacts with the Public Forest Enterprise were made to ensure that forest regeneration measures/forest cover management priorities are integrated in the respective forest management plans. Outcome 4 • The process of preparation of the national-level flood mitigation strategy and an action plan was launched. Following an in-depth review of existing flood risk assessments, conceptualization of additionally required expert input and contracting procedures, the programme continued with completing flood risk assessments for remaining parts of the country by applying a unified methodology. The goal of this process is not to provide a comprehensive flood master plan with site-specific interventions across the entire country, but rather to present a general economic case for country-level flood risk mitigation along with risk-based investment priorities and analysis of funding sources. In this fashion, in addition to the direct benefits for the Polog Region, the implementation of this Swiss-funded programme. • The programme already initiated networking and transfer of knowledge throughout all its components. In order to make best use of experiences so far in the Polog and Southeast planning regions in DRR, the project is facilitating exchange between two UNDP-implemented projects (SECO/SDC funded Polog project and SEE Urban project funded by the EU). The focus on the exchange were the opportunities provided by inter-municipal cooperation in the context of DRR at local level. Furthermore, important international/Swiss experience is already being transferred to key beneficiaries through different consultancies and in the course of the stakeholder events (e.g., by the International Technical Adviser, and urban river flooding management experts from Switzerland) Outcome 5 • Opportunities for inter-university exchanges on issues of relevance through partnership of Swiss and Macedonian research and educational institutions are considered. Discussions are underway with the Faculty of Civil Engineering and Faculty of Forestry which expressed interested in joint research and training. Details on this will be elaborated in the upcoming period as they largely depend on the availability of young researchers with interests in DRR/flood risk management and other related fields. • The project carried preliminary activities in establishing connections with relevant Swiss partners at central and local level government with relevant experience (e.g., DRR, flood risk management, regulation of torrential streams, early warning systems, and insurance), in order to carry out an experience exchange study visit in Switzerland of key stakeholders at national and local levels.
